SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Greater Meridian Health Clinic, Inc. is a non-profit corporation exempt from corporate federal income taxes under Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1954 and from Mississippi income taxes. Therefore, no provision has been made for federal or Mississippi corporate income taxes in the accompanying financial statements. In addition, the Organization has been determined by the Internal Revenue Service not to be a "private foundation" within the meaning of Section 509(a) of the Code. The Organization has analyzed its tax positions taken for filings with the Internal Revenue. It believes that its tax filing positions will be sustained upon examination and does not anticipate any adjustments that would result in a material adverse effect on its financial condition, results of operations, or cash flows. The Organization's federal and state income tax returns for adopted recently issued accounting principles related to uncertain tax positions for 2022, 2021, and 2020 are subject to examination by the federal, state and local taxing authorities, generally for three years after they are filed.
After form 990 is prepared, the organization presents it to the finance committee for review, and if approved, then the 990 is filed with the IRS.

The Organization states in the conflict of interest policy that employees are required to disclose to their supervisor and the Executive Director about any personal business situation or transaction that is in conflict with the interest or purpose of the Clinic.

The CEO salary is determined by an evaluation of the Board of Directors, whereby the results are voted upon by the full Board of Directors based on the availability of funding. Compensation is determined in accordance with hospital and healthcare compensation services.
Key and other employees receive an annual evaluation based on the availability of funding. Compensation reference guide and GMHC policies and related procedures.
The Organization makes it governing documents, conflict of interest policy, and financial statements available to the public upon request.
The CFO, CEO, and designated board members (Finance Committee) meet to discuss and review all questions before submission to the audit firm.
